prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not allowing my gf (28) to be friends with co-worker(of 3+ years) anymore for calling one of their co-workers her "boyfriend"?
A little background, me and my gf live together (3 Months now) but have been on and off for 4 years. She's been friends with this girl for 3+ years. My gf told me straight up that this guy (let's call him Sam from now on) Sam doesn't talk too anyone at their job (plenty of male female associates). But, since he has worked there he "waves" at my gf and is the only person at their job he kinda talks to. I was ok with that. I trusted her since she brought it up. 

I posted yesterday that we go through each other's phones. Well she deleted a few message. Most were innocent "what are you girls wearing tomorrow?". How I know you ask? Well she has a Fitbit and while she deletes her text on her phone her Fitbit takes longer to delete them. (this isn't the point of this post please don't focus or make your decision based off this). But I used the knowledge that she erased messages (she doesn't know her fitbit is betraying her) to let her tell me everything she deleted. Turns out that she deleted a message where her friend said something along the lines of "your boyfriend (Sam) was late to work last night" my gf told me that she ignored the message and moved the conversation on. I believe her because she is under the impression that I read it all (still thinks I hacked her phone when in reality she sank herself. I read one fitbit message).

After finding this out. I said "I don't want you to be friends with her anymore she doesn't respect me as your man and us as a couple". I know some people joke around and sometimes have innocent "work husband's". I'm not ok with either. I believe my gf should had told her friend that it's not ok to call another man that and I don't think her friend had a right to joke like that. 

Am I the asshole for not wanting her to keep that friend anymore? 
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. The user is asking whether the person (the author) is in the wrong for cutting off his girlfriend's friend because the friend referred to another coworker as her boyfriend.

First, the context: The girlfriend and the coworker (Sam) have been working together for over three years. The author was okay with the friendship, trusting his girlfriend's assurance that Sam doesn't talk to anyone else at work. But then he found out through her deleted messages that the friend called Sam her "boyfriend." The author then told his girlfriend he doesn't want her to be friends with her anymore because the friend doesn't respect them as a couple.

Hmm, so the main issue here is whether the author overreacted. Let's break down the key points. The friend used a term ("boyfriend") that the author found disrespectful. But the girlfriend claims she ignored the message and moved on. The author is enforcing his boundaries, but is cutting off the friend entirely justified?

The friend might have been joking or using a casual term without ill intent. However, the author feels disrespected and wants to prevent any such references. But is it fair to end the friendship over a single joke? The girlfriend's reaction is also important—she might feel that the friend was just teasing and not intentionally disrespectful. 

Also, the author's method of finding out (using the Fitbit to check deleted messages) shows that he's been checking her phone. Even though he got the information through her own mistake, the fact that he was monitoring her phone might affect his credibility. The girlfriend might feel betrayed, which complicates the situation.

On the other hand, the author is asserting his boundaries in the relationship. If he's uncomfortable with the term "boyfriend" being used for another man, he has a right to express that. However, cutting off the friend entirely might be too harsh unless there's a pattern of disrespect. One instance of a joke might not warrant ending the friendship, especially if the girlfriend is okay with it and the friend didn't intend harm.

So, is the author in the wrong? It depends on perspective. If the key issue is the friend's lack of respect, then the author has a right to be upset. But cutting off the friend without discussing it with them or the girlfriend might be an overreaction. The author could have asked the girlfriend to address the issue with her friend instead of ending the friendship abruptly. 

Also, the fact that the author used the Fitbit to monitor messages might make others question his trustworthiness, which could color their judgment of his actions. His approach to resolving the issue might be seen as controlling or distrustful, which could be why people might side against him. 

In conclusion, while the author has a right to feel disrespected, his response might be too extreme. Instead of cutting off the friend, he could have communicated his concerns to his girlfriend and asked her to address the issue with the friend. Ending the friendship without giving the friend a chance to explain or change their behavior could be seen as unnecessary. Therefore, the author might be in the wrong because his reaction is disproportionate to the situation.
